thread.title: Edmonton Oilers edge Vancouver Canucks in overtime
thread.title_full: Edmonton Oilers edge Vancouver Canucks in overtime

title: Edmonton Oilers edge Vancouver Canucks in overtime
text:
Oilers 
VANCOUVER — The Edmonton Oilers were looking to build on their best performance of the year Sunday against the Vancouver Canucks and did by stealing a win in overtime. 
Goaltender Anders Nilsson turned away 33 shots, setting the stage for Lauri Korpikoski to score the overtime winner, giving the Oilers a 2-1 victory. 
Korpikoski was sent in alone on a feed from Andrej Sekera and was able to muscle the puck through Canucks goaltender Ryan Miller for the win. 
“We were able to grind out a win,” Korpikoski said. “It’s not always pretty on the road, especially when you play back-to-back, but we’re really pleased how we showed up for the last two periods.” 
The win gave the Oilers their second-consecutive victory, which was highlighted by an outstanding setup from Connor McDavid to Nail Yakupov in the first period. 
While on the power play, the Oilers rookie took a pass in the neutral zone, then slipped between Canucks defenceman Luca Sbisa and winger Jannik Hansen by playing the puck to himself off the boards just inside the blue line. 
McDavid then spotted Yakupov in the slot and feathered a pass to him, allowing the winger to one-time a shot past Miller. 
“He made a really good pass,” Yakupov said. “He wasn’t happy a lot (Sunday), but you’re not going to make beautiful plays every shift. But we tried to make sure we took advantage of our chances. I thought we also played in our zone really hard too. The first goal, we had to play well in our zone before we brought the puck up, so I think we did well there.” 
The Oilers rode their goal and their luck in pulling out the victory as Daniel Sedin had the miss of the year, failing to deposit the puck into an empty net in the third period. 
Sedin got to the puck in the crease after his brother Henrik was stopped by Nilsson on a breakaway. Nilsson slid past the net and Daniel Sedin somehow chipped it up over the crossbar. 
The miss kept the Oilers in the contest. 
“When you watch the top-10 misplays, sometimes you see those,” said Oilers head coach Todd McLellan. “It’s a break we needed and we took advantage of it. You don’t get those very often and that could be the only true break we get in a long, long time, but we took advantage of it.” 
The Canucks out-shot the Oilers 34-24 in the contest and tied the game in the second period as Matt Bartkowski scored his first career goal, drifting a point-shot past Nilsson. 
Bartkowski was able to find the net with centre Bo Horvat creating traffic to the left of the Oilers goaltender. 
McLellan considered challenging the play, but video showed the puck had crossed the goal line before Horvat made contact with Nilsson. 
In the third, after Sedin’s miss, the Canucks had a number of good chances to take the lead. Henrik Sedin found space along the left wing and snapped a shot just wide. 
Later in the period, Nilsson made a diving save on Radim Vrbata as the Canucks turned up the pressure. 
Miller kept the Oilers from stealing the contest in regulation with less than 90 seconds to play, as Yakupov took his own rebound off the end boards and came close to firing the puck through the Canucks goaltender. 
In overtime, the first good chance fell to the Oilers as Taylor Hall and Ryan Nugent-Hopkins broke away on a two-on-one rush. Hall kept the puck and took a shot, but Miller was able to smother the puck. 
The teams traded chances back and fourth before Sekera sent Korpikoski away with a perfectly-weighted backhand pass, 1:46 into the extra frame. 
“Overtime is tough on the goalies, because you see an odd-man rush going our way and if Miller makes the save, you know it’s going to come back to me,” Nilsson said. “It’s a lot of pressure on the goalies, but I like it, it’s fun and I think it’s entertaining for the fans too.” 
The Oilers return home to host the Detroit Red Wings on Wednesday and the Washington Capitals on Friday.
